awd_titl_txt: Molecular Spin Qubits in a One-Dimensional Host
awd_abstract_narration:
A rule of thumb for modern computer technology is that approximately every two years, the number of transistors on a microprocessor chip doubles. This rate of improvement is described by Moore's Law, and has started to falter for a variety of reasons. One new paradigm that may permit continued rapid growth is quantum computing. Quantum computing exploits the laws of quantum mechanics and may solve certain problems that are essentially intractable with conventional computers. The key fundamental unit in a quantum computer is the so called quantum bit (or qubit), in analogy to the classical binary bit. This research aims to understand electron spins in low-dimensional materials and develop a new type of qubit based on these electron spins. A close collaboration between the two universities in this project helps promote partnership between the institutions. This research activity provides interdisciplinary training for the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers involved in this project in the areas of material science, quantum optics, and nanophotonics. It also serves as an exciting opportunity for the training of our next-generation workforce in quantum information science.  

The spin of a single electron is a natural candidate for qubits due to its capability to store and process quantum information. A key challenge in operating an electron spin as a functional qubit is to turn on and off its coupling to the external environment with full control. By establishing a spin-photon interface in the qubit materials, it is possible to efficiently manipulate and readout the spin states using optical techniques. This approach has been successfully implemented in studying several types of naturally occurring defect qubits in bulk materials. To move beyond spin qubits in bulk materials and allow design and control of the qubit systems on the atomic scale, the research team adopts a bottom-up approach to develop molecular spin qubits integrated in low dimensional materials. The full synthetic control of the molecular qubits enables effective tuning of their electronic structures. Molecular design and composition control also allow addressing physical processes that drive spin decoherence. Combining first-principle theory calculations and experimental studies, this research aims to develop a new type of molecular spin qubits that interface optical photons. The material platform established in this research advances understanding of chemistry-enabled qubits and their application in quantum devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, our aim was to gain fundamental understandings of chemically modified single walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs), with a focus on functionalization-introduced new photophysical and spin properties. Within this award, we addressed several key issues that had important contributions to controlled exciton and spin localization in low-dimensional materials. We list the key outcomes of this project below.

  1. Ultrafast trapping of excitons at defect sites. We discovered that the photodynamics of the SWCNTs was strongly affected by the presence and density of quantum defects introduced by the chemical functionalization process. At low defect densities, excitons mainly underwent diffusion-limited first order decay process and exciton-exciton interactions, similar to those in pristine nanotubes. However, with increasing defect densities, trapping of the excitons at the defect sites became the dominant decay channel, which led to the accumulation of excitons at the defect states and depletion of the ground states. These findings shed light on the design of quantum defects that would enable stable and bright near-infrared emission. They also provide critical evidence for achieving population inversion in the functionalized SWCNTs.
  2. Localization of electron spins. In pristine SWCNTs, the 1D nature of the itinerant electrons promotes a Luttinger liquid state. The associated linewidth broadening makes their detection using electron spin resonance measurements unfeasible. However, we observed distinct ESR signals with a Landé g-factor of 2.0037 ± 0.0003 for the chemically functionated SWCNTs. Utilizing temperature dependent ESR measurements, we discovered the magnetic susceptibility of the functionalized SWCNTs followed the Curie law. By comparing the spin and defect densities, we could conclude that the newly emerged spins are associated with the quantum defects. During the chemical functionalization process, unpaired electrons were introduced to the SWCNT sidewalls. These unpaired electrons were likely stabilized due to spreading of the wavefunctions over adjacent carbon atoms. These conclusions were further supported by our density functional theory calculations, which showed that the spins were highly localized at the defect sites.
  3. Demonstration of quantum control operation of electron spin qubits. We measured the spin coherence time, T2, of the localized electron spins to be around 1 µs, and further extended it to 8 µs using dynamical decoupling. This long spin coherence time allowed our demonstration of quantum control operation of the spin qubits. By coherently manipulating the spins using nutation experiments, Rabi oscillation could be clearly observed, which exemplified the capability to rotate the spin qubits arbitrarily to any point on the Bloch sphere. Moreover, we determined the system’s spin-lattice relaxation time T1 to be 13 ms, which was much longer than T2. Our investigation of the decoherence mechanisms revealed two major sources: instantaneous diffusion effect resulting from high local spin densities and the subsequent dipole-dipole interactions; hyperfine coupling of the electron spins with 13C from the nanotubes and 1H from the solvents. These findings were further confirmed by our cluster correlation expansion calculations of the spin coherence times.
  4. Confinement of excitons. Beyond carbon nanotubes, we also explored alternative nanomaterials such as 2D semiconductors. We developed methods to localize and confine excitons in these 2D materials, particularly using local strain engineering and dielectric contrast modification methods.

Broader Impacts: The fundamental knowledge obtained in this project could provide new insights into chemistry-enabled quantum materials and their designs. The supported graduate student and postdoc researchers received interdisciplinary trainings in material science, nanofabrication, spintronics, and quantum optics. This project also provided mentoring for one undergraduate student and eight high school students over summers. Research results from this project were disseminated in peer-reviewed journals, conferences, divisional seminars, and science fairs.
